acts.title: The Humbling Beginning
acts.description: In 1971, you join Fairchild Semiconductor as a junior engineer. The silicon revolution is just beginning, and you'll learn the fundamentals of digital logic by building a simple 4-bit processor from the ground up.

setting.text: The morning sun filters through the tall windows of Fairchild Semiconductor's Mountain View facility. The air carries the faint smell of solder and the hum of oscilloscopes. Engineers in short-sleeved shirts huddle over breadboards, their conversations punctuated by the click of logic probes.

narrative: You step into the digital logic lab for the first time, clutching your employee badge. The space is a maze of workbenches covered in integrated circuits, data sheets, and half-assembled prototype boards.
A woman in a white lab coat notices you and approaches with a warm smile. Her badge reads 'Dr. Sarah Chen - Senior Design Engineer'.

characters.name: Dr. Sarah Chen
characters.title: Senior Design Engineer
characters.bio: A pioneer in digital logic design who helped develop some of the first integrated ALU chips. Known for her patient teaching style and encyclopedic knowledge of Boolean algebra.

dialogues.speaker: Dr. Chen
dialogues.text: Welcome to Fairchild! You must be our new junior engineer. I'm Sarah Chen - I'll be your mentor as you learn the ropes here.

dialogues.speaker: Dr. Chen
dialogues.text: We're building something special. Not just circuits, but the building blocks of computation itself. Ready to get started?

setting.text: Dr. Chen leads you to a workbench in the corner of the lab. On it sits a breadboard with a few wires and a handful of chips scattered nearby.

narrative: She picks up a small black chip with silver legs and holds it up to the light.
This is a 7400 series NAND gate. Four gates in one package. With just this humble chip, you can build anything - adders, multiplexers, entire processors.

technicalNotes.content: NAND gates are 'universal gates' - any Boolean function can be implemented using only NAND gates. This makes them the fundamental building block of digital logic.

dialogues.speaker: Dr. Chen
dialogues.text: Your first task is simple: build a half-adder. It takes two single-bit inputs and produces a sum and a carry. Think you can figure it out?

setting.text: The workbench awaits. Several paths forward present themselves.

narrative: Dr. Chen steps back, giving you space to work. The breadboard, chips, and data sheets are at your disposal.

choices.title: Study the Data Sheet
choices.description: Carefully read the 7400 series documentation to understand the pin configurations and timing characteristics.

choices.title: Dive Right In
choices.description: Start wiring up the breadboard immediately. The best way to learn is by doing.

choices.title: Ask for a Hint
choices.description: Request a quick overview of half-adder logic from Dr. Chen before starting.

setting.text: The lab bench is ready. Oscilloscope humming, logic probe in hand.

narrative: Time to put theory into practice. Build the half-adder circuit using the Micro4 HDL simulator.

objectives.text: Create XOR gate for sum output
Create AND gate for carry output

technicalNotes.content: A half-adder computes: Sum = A XOR B, Carry = A AND B. Remember, XOR can be built from NAND gates: A XOR B = ((A NAND (A NAND B)) NAND (B NAND (A NAND B)))

setting.text: After completing the challenge, Dr. Chen returns to check your work.

dialogues.speaker: Dr. Chen
dialogues.text: Excellent work! You've just taken your first step into digital design. A half-adder is simple, but it's the foundation of everything we build here.

dialogues.speaker: Dr. Chen
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, we'll chain multiple adders together to create a full 4-bit ALU. But for now, take a moment to appreciate what you've accomplished.

narrative: As the afternoon sun casts long shadows across the lab, you realize this is just the beginning of a long journey. The world of digital logic stretches out before you, full of possibilities.
